details.title: Model-based reliability analysis

authors.affiliation: Sandia Nat. Labs., Livermore, CA, USA

p: Rene L. Bierbaum (M'84) received the B.S. degree (1983) in electrical engineering from the University of Nebraska and the M.S. degree (1984) in electrical engineering from Stanford University.

She is a Distinguished Member of the Technical Staff at Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, CA. She is affiliated with the Reliability and Electrical Systems Department at Sandia, working as a reliability analyst for the nuclear weapons program.

authors.name: R.L. Bierbaum

p: Thomas D. Brown received the B.S. degree (1984) in chemical engineering from the University of New Mexico and the M.S. degree (1987) in mechanical engineering from the University of California at Berkeley.
He is a Principal Member of the Technical Staff at Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM. He works as a surety analyst in the Weapon Surety Engineering Department at Sandia.
Thomas J. Kerschen received the B.A. degree (1975) in mathematics from the New Mexico State University and the M.S. degree (1977) in mathematics from the University of Washington.

He is a Distinguished Member of Technical Staff at Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM. He is in the Reliability Assessment Department at Sandia working as a reliability analyst for the nuclear weapons program.

details.abstract: Testing has typically been a key means of detecting anomalous performance and of providing a foundation for estimating reliability for weapon systems. The objective of model-based reliability analysis (MBRA) is to identify ways to capitalize on the insights gained from physical-response modeling both to supplement the information obtained from testing and to better-understand test results. Five general MBRA processes are identified which can capitalize on physical response modeling results to make both quantitative and qualitative statements about product reliability. A case study that explores 1 of these 5 processes was completed and is described in detail. It had the benefits: MBRA can be used to determine a performance baseline against which current and future test results can be compared; during the design process, MBRA can provide tradeoff studies such that development time and required test assets can be reduced; MBRA can be used to evaluate the impact of production and part changes, as well as aging degradation, if they arise during the product life cycle; and MBRA lays the foundation to evaluate anomalies that are observed in a test program. Typically it has been challenging to determine how anomalous behavior can manifest itself under different-but still valid-conditions. One can use modeling to inject hypothesized behaviors under different conditions and observe the consequences.

references.title: Modeling and simulation of reliability for design

context.text: A review article [1] highlights the current state of the tools and capabilities.

references.text: A. Mathewson, P. O'Sullivan, A. Concannon, "Modeling and simulation of reliability for design", Microelectron. Eng., vol. 49, pp. 95-117, Nov. 1999.

references.title: Berkeley reliability tools&#821BERT

context.text: The most widely used of these tools is BERT [2], which offers analysis capabilities for several classes of failure mechanisms in the context of a circuit.

links.abstract: Berkeley reliability tools (BERT) simulates the circuit degradation (drift) due to hot-electron degradation in MOSFETs and bipolar transistors and predicts circuit failure rates due to oxide breakdown and electromigration in CMOS, bipolar, and BiCMOS circuits. With the increasing importance of reliability in today's and future technology, a reliability simulator such as this is expected to serve as the engine of design-for-reliability in a building-in-reliability paradigm. BERT works in conjunct...

references.text: R. H. Tu, E. Rosenbaum, W. Y. Chau, "Berkeley reliability tools̵BERT", IEEE Trans. Computer-Aided Design of Integrat. Circuits Syst., vol. 12, pp. 1524-1534, Oct. 1993.

references.title: A complete radiation reliability software simulator

context.text: There are many published applications and extensions of BERT [3]–[7].

links.abstract: In this paper we describe a simulator which can be used to study the effects on circuit behavior of two radiation phenomena: single event upset (SEU) and total-dose radiation effects. Using this simulator the user can predict the error rate in large circuits due to single event upset. The error rate model described here uses a well established methodology, but for the first time a different choice is made on picking up the sensitive nodes, enabling a quick prediction even for very complex circui...

references.text: P. Pavan, R. H. Tu, E. R. Minami, "A complete radiation reliability software simulator", IEEE Trans. Nuclear Science, vol. 41, pp. 3619-2630, Dec. 1994.

references.title: Circuit-level simulation of TDDB failure in digital CMOS circuits

context.text: There are many published applications and extensions of BERT [3]–[4][7].

links.abstract: An efficient circuit-level simulator for the prediction of time-dependent dielectric breakdown effects in digital CMOS circuits has been developed and integrated into the reliability simulation tool BERT (Berkeley Reliability Tools). The new module enhances the capability of the earlier SPICE-based oxide breakdown simulator by enabling practical simulations of large digital circuits. We discuss burn-in simulation for digital circuits and show that a significant reduction in oxide breakdown failu...

references.text: E. R. Minami, S. B. Kuusinene, E. Rosenbaum, "Circuit-level simulation of TDDB failure in digital CMOS circuits", IEEE Trans. Semiconduct. Manufact., vol. 8, pp. 370-374, Aug. 1995.

references.title: Hot-carrier aging simulations of a voltage controlled oscillator

context.text: There are many published applications and extensions of BERT [3]–[5][7].

references.text: N. Koike, H. Nishimura, M. Takeo, "Hot-carrier aging simulations of a voltage controlled oscillator", IEICE Trans. Electronics, vol. E79, pp. 1285-1288, Sept. 1996.

references.title: Application of circuit-level hot-carrier reliability simulation to memory design

links.abstract: We have applied hot-carrier circuit-level simulation to entire circuits of a few thousand to over 12 K transistors using a simple but accurate degradation model for reliability verification of actual memory products. Previous published applications were small scale (few tens of transistors or individual circuit blocks) or for experimental purposes. By applying simulation to entire circuits, areas with worst degradation are not missed due to simulating only certain circuit blocks. Varying degrada...

references.text: P. M. Lee, T. Seo, K. Ise, "Application of circuit-level hot-carrier reliability simulation to memory design", IEICE Trans. Electronics, vol. E81, pp. 595-601, Apr. 1998.

references.title: A simulation methodology for bidirectional hot-carrier degradation in a static RAM circuit

context.text: There are many published applications and extensions of BERT [3]–[7].

references.text: N. Koike, M. Takeo, K. Tatsuuma, "A simulation methodology for bidirectional hot-carrier degradation in a static RAM circuit", IEICE Trans. Electronics, vol. E81, pp. 959-967, June 1998.

references.title: iTEM: A temperature-dependent electromigration reliability diagnosis tool

context.text: There are numerous other modeling tools that examine a single time- or temperature-dependent failure mechanism [8]–[12], also in a circuit context.

links.abstract: In this paper, we present a new electromigration reliability diagnosis tool (iTEM) for CMOS VLSI circuits. Unlike previous electromigration reliability tools, iTEM can estimate the interconnect temperature rise due to joule heating and heat conduction from the substrate using a newly developed lumped thermal model. By including the temperature effect, iTEM provides much more accurate electromigration reliability diagnosis. Moreover, it is computationally efficient, and can analyze circuit layout...

references.text: C.-C. Teng, Y.-K. Cheng, E. Rosenbaum, S.-M. Kang, "iTEM: A temperature-dependent electromigration reliability diagnosis tool", IEEE Trans. Computer-Aided Design of Integrat. Circuits Syst., vol. 16, pp. 882-893, Aug. 1997.

references.title: ILLIADS-T: An electrothermal timing simulator for temperature-sensitive reliability diagnosis of CMOS VLSI chips

context.text: There are numerous other modeling tools that examine a single time- or temperature-dependent failure mechanism [8]–[11][12], also in a circuit context.

links.abstract: In this paper, we present a new chip-level electrothermal timing simulator for CMOS VLSI circuits. Given the chip layout, the packaging specification, and the periodic input signal pattern, it finds the on-chip steady-state temperature profile and the resulting circuit performance. A tester chip has been designed for verification of ILLIADS-T, and very good agreement between simulation and experiment was found. Using this electrothermal simulator, temperature-dependent reliability and timing pro...

references.text: Y.-K. Cheng, P. Raha, C.-C. Teng, "ILLIADS-T: An electrothermal timing simulator for temperature-sensitive reliability diagnosis of CMOS VLSI chips", IEEE Trans. Computer-Aided Design of Integrat. Circuits Syst., vol. 17, pp. 668-681, Aug. 1998.
